en.53deeddd9df1919c7748ea5d35f7c7a2: This is a modified version of the Glossary of Terms from Access to Insight. We adapt this useful resource with gratitude. Changes include:
en.a52884d4949311176c9a0cc75030ca98: Removing all later texts and references, retaining only references directly to the early texts.
en.444cf1caf43c7c2b28c61cc296e80665: In quite a few cases, terminology and definitions have been changed, corrected, or deleted. However, most of the content is identical.
en.0abdaf0e93b1bd21a4a65abdd3e73e7e: References only include the Pali texts.
en.0ba3c878fc3c05ca0985c5b9b56de823: The list is not meant to be complete, but merely offers a handy guide to some common terms in their most important meanings.
en.0a60bc9e34d0ce4662dceb78c4b19f8b: In the discourses of the Pali canon, this term simply means “about the Dhamma”, and refers to discussions about sometimes abstruse points in the teachings.
en.9cdcf998c23306b73e9195fc382da57c: A later collection of analytical treatises based on lists of categories drawn from the teachings in the discourses, added to the Canon several centuries after the Buddha’s life.
en.c027b2e2b7f03ba68185fc1790ee9930: Intuitive powers that come from the practice of concentration: the ability to display psychic powers, clairvoyance, clairaudience, the ability to know the thoughts of others, recollection of past lifetimes, and the knowledge that does away with mental defilements (see āsava).
en.6d225c7c792c21fb2b61a551209ed187: Determination; resolution; sometimes a term for defilements.
en.6916f7235ff9ef6c9d27e6cdb450a7b8: Timeless; without interval; in this very life.
en.f9fa60837b86ff7ad0fe394836b02842: Unwholesome, unskillful, demeritorious. See its opposite, kusala.
en.6ca4e63fb720c4441b48356b891e12dd: Non-returner. A person who has abandoned the five lower fetters that bind the mind to the cycle of rebirth (see saṃyojana), and who after death will appear in one of the Brahmā worlds called the Pure Abodes, there to attain nibbāna, never again to return to this world. This is the third of the four stages of awakening.
en.4caa72a125859f4e8746fda150233539: Mindfulness of breathing. A meditation practice in which one maintains one’s attention and mindfulness on the sensations of breathing.
en.1cc0272a7c7dcf2352d4252260fe4191: Gradual instruction. The Buddha’s method of teaching Dhamma that guides his listeners progressively through increasingly advanced topics: generosity (see dāna), virtue (see sīla), heavens, drawbacks, renunciation, and the four noble truths.
en.6d8c9f0ab1551aa3f5afd4262f9feeb8: A “worthy one” or “perfected one”; a person whose mind is free of defilement (see kilesa), who has abandoned all ten of the fetters that bind the mind to the cycle of rebirth (see saṃyojana), whose heart is free of mental defilements (see āsava), and who is thus not destined for further rebirth. A title for the Buddha and the highest level of his noble disciples.
en.37270d7f0cdb06b482a26c750899e536: Basis or cause. In the early texts this does not yet have the later sense of “mental object”.
en.4583018e4adeefd58aa774ced23a53bd: Noble person; enlightened individual. An individual who has entered at least the lowest of the four noble paths (see magga). Compare puthujjana (ordinary person).
en.4d661c42e39df8ab3392e021be509fab: Noble Truth. The sense is that the truth itself is noble, and it “ennobles” the one who realizes it. There are four: stress, the origin of stress, the disbanding of stress, and the path of practice leading to the disbanding of stress.
en.cfa3b9ac79a397751ae3025b1741207e: Mental defilement, pollutant, or corruption. Four qualities—sensuality, views, desire for rebirth, and ignorance—that “flow out” of the mind and create the flood of the round of death and rebirth.
en.359cf9939cb39c3aa1e5f6c21e77f189: A race of beings who, like the Titans of Greek mythology, fought the devas for sovereignty over the heavens and lost. See apāya-bhūmi.
en.e9a90c6b0c7a202d6ff497ea43ecb386: Sense field. The inner sense fields are the sense organs: eyes, ears, nose, tongue, body, and mind. The outer sense media are their respective stimuli.
en.43d4075a8bbea467682dcf71f3ac293f: Venerable sir. In the Pali texts, this is used as a vocative in addressing the Buddha or a Buddhist monk. In modern usage it is often used also as a title.
en.5b00953e1e43293e409babd710a9dba7: Existence, life, or rebirth. States of existence that develop first in the mind and can then be experienced as internal worlds and/or as worlds on an external level. There are three levels of existence: on the sensual level, the level of form, and the level of formlessness.
en.38c69237135e15de5f808f25c6b1843d: Mental cultivation or development; meditation. The third of the three grounds for meritorious action. See also dāna and sīla.
en.d86e3cff80b387f378a411ae17767bd7: Female mendicant; Buddhist nun; a woman who has given up the householder’s life to live a life of heightened virtue (see sīla) in accordance with the Vinaya in general, and the Pātimokkha rules in particular. See saṅgha, parisā, upasampadā.
en.525fd49ae861c349d9301a7d4d093e6c: the four kinds of mindfulness meditation (see satipaṭṭhāna);
en.a1e64550a012554f3c90c42a18761910: the eightfold path (magga)—Right View, Right Thought, Right Speech, Right Action, Right Livelihood, Right Effort, Right Mindfulness, Right Immersion.
en.1bddfd80031ac5b2e4743e077610e7e5: A high divinity; an inhabitant of the non-sensual heavens of form or formlessness. Regarded by himself and brahmins as Lord and creator of the universe.
en.6f0b7e9ff7d1a5dee808d2f07ed682b8: Walking meditation, usually in the form of walking back and forth along a prescribed path.
en.c7a22c62ebbea7ef5cb5c3234d5a0515: “Mental”. In the later Abhidhamma, this acquired a special technical sense of “mental concomitant”, in other words, the various psychological factors that accompany consciousness.
en.f2912af0e73e68be470961bff581335a: A cousin of the Buddha who tried to effect a schism in the saṅgha and who has since become emblematic for all Buddhists who work knowingly or unknowingly to undermine the religion from within.
en.c3de491e498943f7d4225a6ea05bb954: “doctrine (dhamma) and discipline (vinaya)”. The Buddha’s own name for the religion he founded.
en.f7147806d5977e4924b40913d297a64d: Element; property, impersonal condition. The four physical elements or properties are earth (solidity), water (liquidity), wind (motion), and fire (heat). The six elements include the above four plus space and consciousness.
en.df21891d83287caac2b549cc11d5a573: using only one set of three robes;
en.673dca85d0b01fc11c4ad83e00e2b748: not by-passing any donors on one’s alms path;
en.364e29aa0899d9121c307ca83ecfeede: eating no more than one meal a day;
en.97540039a7bf0daae9776fcbfc768e50: refusing any food offered after the alms-round;
en.cd24d6e129e123c2c2fc5176d6934c1f: being content with whatever dwelling one has;
en.436d4879fe33dd0ab1057ef6b13fcfbd: The path to convergence or oneness. An epithet derived from the brahmanical Upanishads. In Buddhism, practise of the four kinds of mindfulness meditation leads to immersion or oneness of mind.
en.4210e98a4066f347009be85eb5003407: Admirable friend; a mentor or teacher of Dhamma.
en.658f1bb97bed9af7ad20f6f7cd14ccd2: Kinds of sensual stimuli. The stimuli of the five physical senses: sights, sounds, smells, flavors, and touches.
en.755b9532b950010e60fc21cf74c3a7a5: A ceremony, held in the fourth month of the rainy season, in which a Saṅgha of mendicants receives a gift of cloth from lay people, bestows it on one of their members, and then makes it into a robe before dawn of the following day.
en.9f01fc28ee06664cb824fdf1fb5fe205: Mindfulness immersed in the body. This is a blanket term covering several meditation themes: keeping the breath in mind; being mindful of the body’s posture; being mindful of one’s activities; analyzing the body into its parts; analyzing the body into its physical properties (see dhātu); contemplating the fact that the body is inevitably subject to death and disintegration.
en.d6ad4a48b62a095f44fa64b26897053a: Affairs or phenomena of the world. The standard list gives eight: wealth, loss of wealth, status, loss of status, praise, criticism, pleasure, and pain.
en.b4aaa610bc61ca3e68cb413ea650228f: Knower of the cosmos. An epithet for the Buddha.
en.8647ab9c482873a3dec7667af5f64534: Transcendent; supramundane (see magga, phala, and nibbāna).
en.27b2bc2e23d502aead2e68bcd67eaa6e: Path. Specifically, the path to the cessation of suffering and stress. The four transcendent paths—or rather, one path with four levels of refinement—are the path to stream-entry (entering the stream to nibbāna, which ensures that one will be reborn at most only seven more times), the path to once-returning, the path to non-returning, and the path to arahantship. See phala.
en.252f61d7e5a09903ae9151e47c3c54da: The personification of evil and temptation. In the early texts, treated both as a deity of the sense sphere realm and as a metaphor.
en.9c8925b4d9cbef18863cffab1706e37c: Disenchantment; disillusionment; aversion; disgust; weariness. The skillful turning-away of the mind from the conditioned samsaric world towards the unconditioned nibbāna.
en.4eb178ed87474b938e9637c87ad703ba: Hindrances to immersion—sensual desire, ill will, sloth & drowsiness, restlessness & anxiety, and doubt.
en.9f348d2fea9ae530acf1cb90bef48b7e: Referring inwardly; to be brought inward; in reference to oneself. An epithet for the Dhamma.
en.539e82520e9fadfd9133f4eb9e53c372: Private Buddha. One who, like a Buddha, has gained Awakening without the benefit of a teacher, but who lives a solitary life without establishing a dispensation. The early texts refer to them a number of times but with few details.
en.ec7a9704c1c873689268700eda6c9ae5: Discernment; insight; wisdom; intelligence; common sense; ingenuity.
en.3c0a55a5490b2d27bb0c2871c130852f: The tendency of the mind to proliferate issues from the sense of “self”.
en.6acdb8b17e2d5f41f7c6cdda551c240c: The basic code of monastic discipline, consisting of 227 rules for monks (bhikkhus) and 311 for nuns (bhikkhunīs). See Vinaya.
en.b039f547ebe72b94ae358b0f4b8acac4: Fruition. Specifically, the fruition of any of the four transcendent paths (see magga).
en.ba976f5e7596e0bc013fcb0e2eb4c0c5: Honor; respect; devotional observance; worship and offerings to deities.
en.81fca196ce3e29cf66c83a388424714b: One of the many-folk; a “worlding” or ordinary person who has not yet realized any of the four stages of Awakening (see magga). Compare ariya-puggala.
en.488487d7119f91869a7c986f8d74ca18: Faith. A confidence in the Buddha that gives one the willingness to put his teachings into practice. Faith becomes unshakable upon the attainment of stream-entry (see sotāpanna), as the teachings have been confirmed in ones’ own experience.
en.8ad28d9ef04480c35f772f6591920bf4: (exclamation) “It is well”; an expression showing appreciation or agreement.
en.e5b9daf846c6bd6e4110ddd1872c5d9e: Once-returner. A person who has abandoned the first three of the fetters that bind the mind to the cycle of rebirth (see saṃyojana), has weakened the fetters of sensual passion and resistance, and who after death is destined to be reborn in this world only once more.
en.c2a1eb3d4055615b52ce31997b06ec70: “Sage of the Sakyans”; an epithet for the Buddha.
en.72132af686cca9dfde6aba19775d7752: Topics of effacement (effacing defilement)—having few wants, being content with what one has, seclusion, uninvolvement in companionship, energy, virtue (see sīla), immersion, wisdom, release, and the direct knowing and seeing of release.
en.e162b953a48cb0792e9a8d086f48ecff: A being in the process of becoming reborn.
en.57c56685b2b2d0c1bdcc403f89481ec5: Conventional reality; convention; relative truth; supposition; anything conjured into being by the mind.
en.852ba64e154cdbaca516c6e7304e85cb: Transmigration; the round of death and rebirth. See vaṭṭa.
en.8fb972e846ff1d315f77be90a4073374: A sense of awe or inspiration when confronted with spiritual realities; especially a sense of urgency to practice.
en.789d47c4c2e0f09f6337e31b6262e432: Effective in this very life; immediately apparent; visible here and now. An epithet for the Dhamma.
en.e7fa49fb23df8e2bf9bd455fb84d6ea5: the “monastic Saṅgha” (communities of Buddhist monks and nuns) in whom lay followers take refuge;
en.bc89c3aec9befd53a6851fd5913536ba: those followers of the Buddha, lay or ordained, who have attained at least stream-entry (see sotāpanna), the first of the transcendent paths (see magga) culminating in nibbāna.
en.6dedf1014f6d147d194379e089d14a60: Message, instruction, bidding. The dispensation, doctrine, and legacy of the Buddha; the Buddhist religion (see Dhamma-vinaya).
en.5f7592279c590bfc27644e2cf8769901: Kinds of mindfulness meditation; foundations or establishments of mindfulness—body, feelings, mind, and the principles of the causality that govern the mind. The seventh of the eight path factors, this refers primarily to “meditation”, in other words, what we do when we sit to meditate. The four aspects represent a gradually deepening process of meditation, as exemplified in mindfulness of breathing, which is the primary example of this practice. The first three of these are focused on settling and stilling the mind, and the last on developing insight.
en.e816a0e023a43bc26c217feb6d30569a: Virtue, morality. The quality of ethical and moral purity that prevents one from falling away from the eightfold path. Also, the training precepts that restrain one from performing unskillful actions. Sīla is the second theme in the gradual training (see anupubbī-kathā), the second of the seven treasures (see dhana), and the first of the three grounds for meritorious action (see dāna and bhāvanā).
en.92b1d8744779f8c467c56090e8b5b1c8: Boundary or territory which defines the limits of a particular monastic Saṅgha for the purpose of formal acts such as upasampadā, pātimokkha recitation, settling of disputes, etc.
en.30e7a474eda3d53dce5babb7095dcd00: Stream winner. A person who has abandoned the first three of the fetters that bind the mind to the cycle of rebirth (see saṃyojana) and has thus entered the “stream” flowing inexorably to nibbāna, ensuring that one will be reborn at most only seven more times, and only into human or higher realms.
en.4a6760cc4483d77bd15e64324b6a98c0: Originally, a tumulus or burial mound enshrining relics of a holy person—such as the Buddha—or objects associated with his life. Over the centuries this has developed into the tall, spired monuments familiar in temples in Thailand, Sri Lanka, and Burma; and into the pagodas of China, Korea, and Japan.
en.db1279d4d3afe8ce4d51014104405f1e: Well-faring; going (or gone) to a good destination. An epithet for the Buddha.
en.dc1d4aec261aba537cf64acd0caa67e9: The purifying “heat” of ascetic practices. In pre-Buddhist systems like the Jains, this refers to self-mortification, which was believed to create a physical heat in the body that burned off defilements. The Buddha adapted it to refer to his own path in a purely psychological sense.
en.1e19422785b44f7f5e550b20d3f31cb8: The “Realized One”, a frequent epithet for the Buddha, although occasionally it also denotes any of his arahant disciples. The sense is that of someone who has realized or embodied the truth in its highest form. The term became subject to extensive exegesis in the commentaries.
en.b4ec9f0ba18cc277ab762a7b597931f4: The “Triple Gem” consisting of the Buddha, Dhamma, and Saṅgha—ideals to which all Buddhists turn for refuge. See tisarana.
en.955bedb9a8bb9bf556fb05eb42a96212: The “Threefold Refuge”—the Buddha, Dhamma, and Saṅgha. In this context, the refuge for the lay community is the mendicant Saṅgha. See tiratana.
en.7f13f0ea497a57fb8a683b1c8896a44d: Grasping; attachment; sustenance for becoming and birth—attachment to sensuality, to views, to precepts and practices, and to theories of the self.
en.025301ccea519d6881a3007741de1844: Acceptance; full ordination as a bhikkhu or bhikkhunī. See pabbajjā.
en.eab74ffaf91c2bad2f56d54d95823da6: A male/female lay follower of the Buddha. Compare parisā.
en.92e583522ea8fee69c85410189edb45a: Observance day or “sabbath”, corresponding to the phases of the moon, on which Buddhist lay people gather to listen to the Dhamma and to observe special precepts. On the new-moon and full-moon uposatha days monks assemble to recite the Pātimokkha rules.
en.bce99a1f5e5531b6b741ef3bc08cae88: Rains Retreat. A period from July to October, corresponding roughly to the rainy season, in which each monk is required to live settled in a single place and not wander freely about.
en.ebfe4db1add9acdd67f633128a0a1df5: The cycle of birth, death, and rebirth. See saṃsāra.
en.d4066f60a7a63e2727a4ea6a5e6b907f: The ancient name for the Indian lunar month in spring corresponding to our April-May. According to tradition, the Buddha’s birth, Awakening, and Parinibbāna each took place on the full-moon night in the month of Visākha. These events are commemorated on that day in the Visākha festival, which is celebrated annually throughout the world of Theravāda Buddhism.
en.f9c205419fb3a82243766346bac936e1: Clear knowledge; genuine awareness; science (specifically, the cognitive powers developed through the practice of immersion and wisdom).
en.2da447e35f3979a3921903f30eb126d4: Consummate in knowledge and conduct; accomplished in the conduct leading to awareness or cognitive skill. An epithet for the Buddha.
en.4a92ed5b93d5322038754277ec86d4c8: Clear intuitive insight or discernment into physical and mental phenomena as they arise and disappear, seeing them for what they actually are—in and of themselves—in terms of the three characteristics (see ti-lakkhaṇa) and in terms of suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the way leading to its cessation (see ariya-sacca).
en.f0822b1c6ad349049bdaa5d7b13b6b23: Spirit. One of a class of powerful “non-human” beings—sometimes kindly, sometimes murderous and cruel—corresponding roughly to the fairies and ogres of Western fairy tales. In later years, these came to be considered mainly malevolent, but in the Buddha’s day they were morally ambiguous, and in fact were commonly worshiped as deities.
en.468f479bb1c8e962f33de687d0daafbc: The original source of this Glossary was released under the following terms:
